awd_titl_txt: Summer Research Conference in Statistics and Biostatistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Summer Research Conference in Statistics and Biostatistics will be held in Jekyll Island, Georgia on June 4-7, 2017. This meeting is the 53rd in a sequence of annual conferences. Its purpose is to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of current research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to give motivation and direction to further research progress. The conference focuses on young researchers, placing them in close proximity to leaders in the field for person-to-person interactions in a manner not possible at most other meetings. Speakers will present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups. With the travel support provided by this award, students will attend and present their research in posters to be reviewed by more experienced researchers.

The Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS) is a consortium of statistics and biostatistics programs in the South, with member programs at 45 universities in 16 states in the region. This project will fund student participation in the 2017 Summer Research Conference (SRC) sponsored by SRCOS. The meeting is particularly valuable for students and faculty from smaller schools in the region, affording them the opportunity to participate and interact closely with internationally-known leaders in the field without the cost of travel to distant venues. It will strengthen the research of the statistics and biostatistics community as a whole, and particularly in the relatively underdeveloped southern region. The conference's five session topics are Complex Spatial Environmental Problems, Statistical Education, Functional Data Analysis, Causal Inference, and Integrative Omics. More details can be found at the conference web site http://web1.sph.emory.edu/srcos/.

por.por_cntn:
The Summer Research Conference (SRC) is an annual research conference sponsored by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS). Since the inception of the SRC, the purposes of the conference are to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to give motivation and direction to further research progress, particularly for young researchers, in a manner not ordinarily possible at other meetings. The meeting is particularly valuable for graduate students, isolated statisticians, and faculty from smaller regional schools in the Southern Region. Each year, the location of the conference is chosen to be at a drivable distance for researchers in the Southern Region, thus affording them the opportunity to participate and interact closely with internationally-known leaders in the field without the cost of travel to distant venues. Speakers present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups. As such, speakers, session chairs, and discussants make themselves accessible for informal discussions of their research as well as formal presentations.

On the second day of the conference, the NSF/R.L. Anderson Student Poster Session for graduate students is featured. An overwhelming majority of faculty and senior researchers stay and view the student posters. The Student Poster Session includes a competition, with student posters judged by leaders in the field. The Student Poster Session provides an excellent opportunity for the young scholars to gain experience and obtain feedback. Awards in honor of SRCOS founders are presented that evening at the conference banquet. A separate poster session for young faculty and isolated statisticians allows them a means of participation.

The 53rd Annual Summer Research Conference (SRC) was held June 4th - June 7th, 2017 in Jekyll Island, Georgia at the Villas by the Sea Resort. It was co-organized by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS) and the University of Kentucky and hosted by Emory University Department of Biostatistics and Bioinformatics. Eighty scholars from institutions across the country (Michigan to Florida, the Carolinas to California) participated. The website for the meeting is http://web1.sph.emory.edu/srcos/, and it contains program details, abstracts, and photos of conference activities.

Thanks to NSF support for students, limited SRCOS funds from registrations and membership fees could be used to provided support for two internationally renowned keynote speakers: Marc Genton of King Abdullah University of Science and Technology and Marina Vanucci of Rice University. Discussants for these keynote speakers were Jianua Huang, of Texas A&M University and Faming Liang of the University of Florida, respectively. Dr. Qi Long of Emory University and Dr. Amanda Herring of Baylor University organized five additional stimulating invited oral sessions, each featuring one senior and two additional outstanding faculty speakers. The after dinner speaker, Dr. Lance Waller, from Emory University, totally surprised Dr. Kutner by awarding him with a SRCOS lifetime achievement award for his many generous contributions of time and energy to SRCOS over the past 30+ years.

The NSF/R.L. Anderson Student Poster Session featured poster presentations from 31 graduate students, representing 15 graduate programs across the Southern Region. Travel awards were provided by funding from the National Science Foundation, with additional support from the American Statistical Association (ASA) and SRCOS. These awards enabled students, in many cases representing programs with limited travel budgets, to experience a significant scientific conference firsthand. They interacted closely with leading researchers in the field in a manner that is not possible at larger national or international meetings (which would also be prohibitively expensive for many of these students to attend). The M. Clinton Miller award for Best Student Poster went to Arnab Chakraborty from North Carolina State University. R. L. Anderson poster awards went to both Xiaoming Dong from Florida State University and Jianxuan Liu from the University of South Carolina.

The winner of the 2017 fifth annual Kutner/ASA best poster award for a junior faculty member was Karl Gregory from the University of South Carolina. There were 9 faculty contributions. In addition to a generous contribution from Mike Kutner, funds from ASA, SRCOS and the National Institute of Statistical Sciences (NISS) Affiliates Fund helped defray the cost of attendance for these faculty participants.

The co-chairs of the scientific program were Dr. Qi Long of Emory University and Mandy Hering of Baylor University, together with SRCOS officers. The faculty and student poster sessions were coordinated by Ed Boone and Qin Wang, respectively, both from Virginia Commonwealth University. Mike Kutner from the Emory University coordinated all local arrangements in Jekyll Island, and Arny Stromberg from the University of Kentucky provided additional administrative support.
